reviewText: There's a scene where the horribly facially deformed Rocky is verbally accosted in the hallway at his highschool by another student who tells him to take off his mask. Rocky grabs this other teenager and slams him against the lockers replying, "I'll take of my mask when you take off yours" and that's one of the coolest lines I ever heard in a movie.If you have a narcissistic or low self-esteem person in your life or anybody that feels sorry for themself too much have them watch MASK (not THE MASK). The acting is great. Cher is Rocky's mother, Sam Elliot is Cher's biker boyfriend and Eric Stoltz is Rocky. Peter Bogdanovich directed. In the film a poem written by the real-life Rocky is read:These things are good:Ice cream and cake,A ride on a Harley,Seeing monkeys on a tree,The rain on my tongue,And the sun shining on my face.These things are a drag:Dust on my hair,Holes in my shoes,No money in my pocket,And the sun shining on my face.
summary: Happy Halloween: Take off your mask

reviewText: SPOILERSI watch this on tv when it comes on now and then...Sort of sad yet inspirational as others reviewers have said...Rocky Dennis played by Eric Stoltz has a messed up face--or "lionitis"...he overcomes mocking and teasing by believing in himself, and not taking no crap from anyone.. he's part of a motorcycle gang--more like Cher who plays his mother is...Rocky meets a blond blind girl who "sees" Rock for whohe really is....One scene is cool though...as Rocky is walking by in theschool hallway- he overhears another guy bad mouthing him!!So Rocky walks up to him, and slams him against the lockersaying, "I'll take off my mask if you take yours offyou son of a ___ "!!!  I don't blame him....How the make up for Rocky was done I have no clue,but it's amazing...!! The only part of Erik Stoltzwe can see in the movie of his real face is his eyes...Feel good movie!!

reviewText: This new directors cut of "Mask" blows away the orginal DVD release. I'm not going to go on about how great the movie is, by now everyone already knows that. I will talk about this edition however. First of all the print is far clearer and more crisp than the original DVD issue. Next of course is the inclusion of the original Bruce Springsteen soundtrack which was recorded but never used in the theatrical and home video releases. In it's place was a Bob Seger soundtrack which was great, but not the original choice. The movie was shot with Springsteen in mind and in fact Rocky has a Springsteen poster hanging in his room. But Bruce is back and used to great effect. His music was used to set a timeline which was lost when the Seger songs were used.Also included are 8 mins of deleted scenes that have been edited back into the film. One of these scenes (which was sort of referred to in the theatrical version) is a song sung by Rusty (Cher) and Rocky (Eric Stoltz). The song is "Little Egypt" and the scene runs about 4 mins. The other scene is one where one of the bikers dies and his funeral, again this was never before seen.And finally, there is an easter egg of sorts, at the very end of credits, after a minute or two, Cher comes on screen and speaks about the craniofacial disease and how you can help.I've always loved the Seger music in the film, particularly "Roll Me Away" at the end. But the Springsteen music works very well too, and as I said, is used as a timeline.Director Peter Bogdonovich does a commentary as well as a 20 min interview about the movie. As I said in my headline, if you love this movie you will want this new edition, it's well worth it.
summary: If you love this movie, pick up this new version!

reviewText: `Mask' is the type of film that moves you to tears.  It is genuinely sweet and sincere and heartbreaking as well as heartwarming.  It is true that the film can, at times, feel forced and manipulative, but who doesn't like having their feelings manipulated in this manner.  The true story of Rocky Dennis is inspirational and poignant and one that we all should take to heart; and `Mask' gives us the opportunity to do just that.The film recounts the final year of Rocky's life.  Growing up with a rare disease (craniodiaphyseal dysplasia) was not easy for Rocky, but with the support from his very strong and very loving mother Rusty, Rocky was able to make it through.  Teased by other kids and humiliated by teachers, Rocky learned at a young age to form a thick skin, and his mother's defensive and free-spirited attitude helped Rocky to realize that he was no different than anyone else and thus didn't deserve to be treated differently.  The film also portrays Rocky's relationship with his mother and his struggle to clean her up (she was heavy into drugs and this caused problems between her and Rocky).  He was a very strong boy, a very stable force in his mother's life and he made a huge impact on all who came in contact with him.Like I mentioned, the film is at times quite manipulative.  It is a dramatized account of the real Rocky Dennis's life, but that is to be expected.  It falls into the clichéd family/drama moments (the aggravated confrontation that leads to a regretful slapping of a child...the conveniently placed shelf of beer mugs prime for smashing in a fit of emotional rage) and while these moments are unnecessary, I'd be lying if I said they weren't effective.What is necessary and equally effective is the acting, which is, for the most part, outstanding.  Reportedly Cher was quite upset that her performance was not recognized by Oscar.  That in itself seems pretty presumptuous, since to expect you will be Oscar nominated is rather arrogant; but then I saw her performance and quite honestly, it was better than half the nominees.  As Rusty, Cher is above and beyond outstanding.  She emulates every raw and passionate emotion rolling through this woman's body.  She captures the love, the fear, the depression, the pride; everything this woman stood for is presented for us accurately.  Eric Stoltz has a tough job of acting through makeup, which means that he has to do a lot more with his eyes than under normal circumstances.  Many have praised him for his portrayal of Rocky, and I will not knock him, but in all honesty, to me, he was the weakest link here.  I was more moved by Cher's portrayal of his mother than I was of Stoltz performance; but that is just me.  Sam Elliott is strong as the father figure in his life; Gar, and Laura Dern has a beautifully sincere turn as Diana, the blind girl who falls in love with Rocky.The film is touching, as to be expected, and in all its `Ron Howardesque' ways it manages to choke out the cry-baby in all of us.  `Mask' is a very tender film that tells a very beautiful story of love and strength and the power to overcome all obstacles presented before us.  Rocky was born with a deficiency but he never allowed that to factor into his life.  He lived each and every day to the fullest, and that is an inspiration for all of us, especially those of us who tend to take life for granted.

reviewText: I know that the original idea for the movie involved using Bruce Springsteen songs since Rocky Dennis was a fan of his; however, the movie was released with Bob Seger songs, and that is the way I remember it growing up.  Taking the Seger songs out of the movie took away the nostalgia for me.  Moreover, I believe the Bob Seger songs fit the movie much better than the Springsteen songs.  I am a fan of Bruce Springsteen, but I believe his songs don't fit in the movie very well ... to be honest, I found them to be annoying.  Furthermore, in my opinion, the extra scenes in the movie don't fit very well either.  I watched this version once, but I have a copy of the original theatrical release of this movie, which is the version I will watch when I want to see this movie again.  If I had known that Bob Seger's songs were removed from the Director's Cut version (and that there was no option to watch the original version on the dvd), I would have not purchased it.
summary: Disappointed that the Bob Seger songs were removed from the movie

reviewText: Viewed: 5/12Rate: 105/12: The life of Rocky Dennis as portrayed in Mask and the understanding of what is a craniodiaphyseal dysplasia...Peter Bogdanovich outdid himself with this film after he made The Last Picture Show, a haunting tale in a small Texas town. Mask is a beautiful, moving film with a surprise but somber ending. The performances by everybody are top-notch with the real winners in Cher and Eric Stoltz. Although Laura Dern did an excellent job playing the blind character, I just find it a bit insulting to see why they couldn't get somebody else who is actually blind to play the role. A couple of firsts for the film are as follows. This is the first film ever to win the Academy Award for Best Makeup. This was a richly deserved award because when you think about it, you would want the character with a deformed face to speak without the face crumbling apart, a first ever technique. Secondlly, Mask is the first film ever with Bruce Springsteen songs although they weren't used until twenty years later in a Director's Cut edition. All in all, Mask is an outstanding film. By the way, the special from the DVD with Peter Bogdanovich is a must-see, and you will see why he is very intelligent when it comes to making movies.

reviewText: Rocky Dennis, the central character in this movie, proves without a doubt that true beauty lies within.  Although he was hideously deformed, he possessed a beautiful soul and attempted to always reach for the stars,  despite the considerable obstacles standing in his path.  Although he was  not destined to have a long life, his story and his heart will live on  forever through this movie.  A true tearjerker and a lesson to us to keep  dreaming and always try our hardest.  Wonderful.  This movie deserves more  than five stars.

reviewText: What mainly makes Mask such a classic is the fact that the actor who plays the teenager in the film with the unusual Mask disease opened millions of peoples eyes on this very rare and devastating disease that's unfortunately very real.  Back in the mid 80's the disease only affected about 22 million people in the world, but who knows if that number has increased or decreased today.This story will touch you on many unexplainable levels because you begin to feel compassion for people who have to suffer with the disease while getting to know Eric Stoltz's character develop, and you will even begin to see that people who have to deal with the disease can be just like you and me, if you're willing to get over how they look and just accept them as normal people.In the case of Eric Stoltz's character with the Mask disease (based on a true story of someone who really had the disease and died in 1978) you will see how intelligent he was, how easy it was for people to fall in love with him because of his likeable personality, and you will even see how brave he is, and how he doesn't get annoyed or take it personally when someone makes fun of how he looks.  When you consider all these things, you begin to realize how most everyday people aren't able to measure up because most normal people (including me) sometimes tend to take unimportant things seriously that mean absolutely nothing in the grand scheme of things.  The person who suffered with the Mask disease was all about having fun, living life, and not letting a horrible disease get in the way of his dreams.So Mask is a terrific movie with an award-winning performance by Cher and Eric Stoltz.  It doesn't even matter if you don't care for Cher's music- it's her performance that really strikes you hard and makes you a fan of her acting abiliities.  A fantastic movis this one is.

reviewText: An engaging drama about a 16-year-old boy, Rocky Dennis (played by Eric Stoltz), who has a terribly disfiguring bone disease (same illness as the Elephant Man), but also has an incredibly positive outlook on life to go with it. Cher is his mother, who runs around with bikers and takes dope. It's a case of the child being the father to the woman, yet, although he would like his mother to change her ways, he is not critical of her. Her biker friends and Rocky get along marvelously, like an extended family. Cher treats the boy like hard tacks, which seems harsh at times, but is basically best for all concerned. The only misstep is the teenage romance between Rocky and a blind girl played by Laura Dern: it's overy sentimental (it reminded me of the blind girl in FRANKENSTEIN). Perhaps the pathos run a bit thick, but the movie is a moving experience despite that. Based on a true story. Worth a watch.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I first watched this as a teenager nearly 20 years ago, I didn't expect it to move me so much as a rather more cynical 30 something, but it did. There's really not much to fault with this film. A simple tale of Rocky Dennis, tragically disfigured by a degenerative illness, and his attempts to overcome prejudice, fit in at his local All-American highschool and, of course, get a girl. In lesser hands, and with a celeb such as Cher heading the cast list, this could easily have turned into something sugar coated and schmalzy. Yet though the feel good moments come thick and fast, Rocky discovers that in this capricious world, courage and niceness do not guarantee a storybook ending. As the movie progresses, it becomes increasingly heartrending to watch. Eric Stolz, as the boy (based on a real life character) is so natural and engaging that within minutes you have forgotten the layers of makeup which turn him into someone horribly deformed, and consequently feel his pain as he encounters prejudice and cruelty outside of his 'family', the protective biker group, and of course, Cher, playing the mother in a very fine big screen debut.In the genre of 'overcoming tragedy and the odds' movies, this is surely one of the best, yet also one of the most painful.
summary: A beautiful film about a beautiful boy
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have watched Mask quite a few times over the years.  Everytime I catch it on tv, I will watch it, partly because the acting of Cher and Eric Stoltz in this movie is amazing.  The story is also solid gold.  A disfigured boy named Rocky Dennis has to deal with his drug-using mom played by Cher, the pain of his disease, and the struggle of trying to fit in with the "normal" crowd in high school.  The character of Rocky Dennis is kind, smart, and creative.  If you watch this film, you will love this kid by the time the credits roll, or before.  Eric Stoltz should have won an oscar for his acting in Mask.  Watch his body language, he is full of hope, and sadness.  His acting trancends anything a coventional drama could offer.The Director's cut is a little different than the theatrical release, with around four fantastic deleted scenes thrown back in, and the musical score that Peter Bogdanovich wanted all along, Bruce Springsteen.  While I'm not the biggest fan of Springsteen,(the Bob Segar score is what I'm used to) It sounds good.  Universal has really done it up for this release.  You get an audio commentary by Bogdanovich, and also a twenty minute feature on the origins of Mask.  Did I mention it's in DTS?  There are movies to rent, and movies to own.  This one belongs in your dvd collection.

reviewText: Inspired by a true story, I can't get over how profound this story is. The unfolding of a young man's struggle to wade through life with a facial deformity is strong with deep emotions. The movie exposes true cruelty in human nature, but also a capacity for love. Stoltz and Cher are burning with talent in this one! A rites of passage not only for youths, but also struggling adults, for in many ways Cher's character has a longer road down maturity lane than her teenage son.Another great movie along this same vein is 'Powder'.Chrissy K. McVay - Author

reviewText: It's curious that Cher didn't get an Oscar nod for this, clearly the best work of her acting career. "Mask" brings Cher as a drug-abusing motorcycle mama together with a shattering deformity in her 16-year-old straight-laced but practical son, magnificently played by Eric Stoltz. Together, mother and son travel the path toward social acceptance of the disease that makes Rocky an initial outcast before he earns through his own acceptance the validation and respect of those in his world. But mother and son diverge tempestuously on the issue of drugs, and Rocky fights in vain to convince his free-willed mother to stop until, by his own acceptance of it, he finally wins. "Mask" showcases Cher's incredible range as an actress, and she ought to have gotten Academy recognition, at least in the form of a nomination. She carries the emotional devastation of her son's death heart-wretchingly, and the viewer will be profoundly moved with a sense of loss for Rocky, a real-life person who endured the pains of his screen character. It's a moving experience, and humbling, too, for Rocky's station in life shows us that the burden we bear will always be topped by the burden of someone else.

reviewText: I remember seing this tearjerker back in '85 on video only because I'm an Elliott fan, but quite surprisingly, ended up liking it. (-Mostly because it features Lynyrd Skynyrd on the soundtrack, actually.) A heartwarming story about the troubled life of a biker-mom (!) and her different son vs. the world. Though based on a true story, much of the action is naturally (over)played for dramatic effect. It's certainly Cher's finest moment, and Stoltz showed an acting talent he hasn't shown since. (-Apart from "The Fly 2", of course.) Stoltz's friend by the way, is that annoying kid who got neck-knifed in "Friday The 13th, Part 4". If you like movies that make you cry at the end and happy it's not your life, then you'll want this DVD for your collection.

reviewText: One of the best films of the 1980's, or anytime. Wonderfully moving true story of Rocky Dennis, a young man suffering from a disfiguring disease, and the immesurable courage he displayed. This film will make most of us, with our daily "problems", feel like the superficial, shallow, self-pitying , contemptuous, overly image -conscious, ungrateful beings that some of us (I'm just as guilty) often are. Cher is miraculous in this film, playing the all too human, but ultimatley incredibly brave Rusty, Rocky's mother. She gives a performance that, in its' "reality", is second to almost none of recent memory. Equally moving is Eric Stoltz as Rocky, the young man who does not let the cruelty that we humans sometimes inflict upon each other for being "different" get in the way of his experiencing the already elusive joys of life and love. His "Rocky" displays more courage, insight, and forgiveness than most of us could conjure up under the best of conditions. I truly feel the players were guided by the spirit of Rocky, and, in that, were dedicated in letting his incredible spirit and bravery  shine through, without them being overly self-absorbed about giving a great "performance". And it shows, as here, they are all at their best.  Just a superb movie about a superb human being who wasn't here for long, but who's life taught many. I have actually popped in this film when feeling in need of an attitude adjustment after drowning in pools of self-pity. It always works. Try it the next time you're cursing the heavens for that zit on the end of your nose. Most movies are merely entertaining, at best.(Even that's becoming a rarity.) But it's not often that a movie is not only a flawlessly  crafted entertainment experience  but, also, a sometimes life altering lesson. "Mask" is such a film. You will be inspired by the noble life of Rocky Dennis... a BEAUTIFUL person.

reviewText: What a terrific person. How he could make so many friends despite his disease was very nice. The movie is full of drama and it's topped off with a very sad, but predictable, ending. reviewText: I've lost count of how many times I've watched this movie over the years. After watching the "Director's Cut" a few nights ago, I realized that it gets better each time. I wouldn't say this new version is better than the original; I did like the extra footage, but I much prefer the Bob Seger soundtrack. After watching the new version with the Springsteen soundtrack, I put on the original version and skipped to the end credits. Hearing Seger's "Roll Me Away" while the credits roll is almost a spiritual experience. To quote Roger Ebert: "'Mask' is a wonderful movie, a story of high spirits and hope and courage."If you don't own this wonderful movie, I encourage you to buy a used copy of the original version as soon as possible!

reviewText: A magnificent and completely wonderful film based on the life of physically handicapped (only because society made him so) teen Rocky Dennis.That's all the summary I'm going to give because this is such a magical film from start to finish that to say anything more may take away from a first time viewer the surprise and amazement that comes with each passing scene.I will say this, though, this is one of those rare movies where the casting job was done flawlessly.  All the actors and actresses in this motion picture were born to play these roles.  Eric Stoltz (Rocky), Cher (Rusty) and Sam Elliot (Gar) were particularly outstanding.  Laura Dern also gives a brief, but very beautiful, performance as Rocky's very special love interest.If you haven't seen this movie yet, PLEASE make it a point to do so as soon as possible.  I assure you, you won't be disappointed.
summary: A Winner from Beginning to End!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is an incredible movie, about a deformed child whose mother runs with a biker gang and as a result, he was raised around people of this ilk. But instead of having a low sense of self, he is surrounded by people who love him. The day he enters into a new school, his mother and the gang accompany him. At first he is afraid, but the support he has from his mother (played by Cher)is more than enough to get him through. He is a bright kid who has street sense and a kind heart.You know what is going to happen and the morning Cher comes into his room to wake him for school, only the most coldhearted can hold back the tears. This movie is about the love of life and how powerful support from peers and family can be. But this kid's handicap can nowhere compare with that of black kids who are castigated and locked out simply becuase of skin color. As a teacher myself, I recommend this movie to middle school kids as part of their "ethnic studies" requirement. They might not be able to deal with the race issue, but "Mask" will teach them the value of character, and that the old saying is correct; "The strength of criticism lies only in the weakness of the person being criticized." Think about it -- and get this movie; don't rent it, BUY it!
summary: Mask: Now You Know How Black Kids Feel

reviewText: Even someone with a heart of stone will feel for the characters featured in this film, which is based on a true story.Both Cher & Eric Stoltz give moving performances, as a biker babe mother 'addicted' to drink and drugs, and a son, who can't get a girl, and is severely facially deformed.I originally saw this movie quite a few years, and only remembered the scene where he's in high school, and he talks about being from Planet Vulcan.Of course, the facial disease Rocky Dennis has is fatal, so obviously, you know what the ending will be. And the tears ended up tripping me - this is another film that I can add to my "Films I Cry At" list. My mum grabbed it, as she loves true stories, and it's not a film I will ever watch again - I hate crying at films!!! It's only a story is what I keep getting told, but it doesn't work. But you feel for the characters so much.The real Rusty Dennis apparently was a consultant to the great Cher on this movie, and is now rumoured to be battling a drink & drug addiction - and can you blame her? The Cher gave when she found Eric Stoltz had died in his sleep, was almost too realistic.Cher gives a great performance in this movie. It's one of the very rare movies where she isn't wooden - although she does advertise her plastic surgeon a lot. This is a movie to watch purely for Cher, to see her before she overdone the plastic surgery, and is does a farewell tour every couple of years.Eric Stoltz is unrecognisable in his role of Rocky. He must have had a very boring time sitting for so long in make-up!A very moving film, and totally worth watching!

reviewText: Director Peter Bogdanovich's take on the true story of the craniofacially deformed Rocky Dennis is a moving motion picture experience that doesn't manipulate the viewer with treacly schmaltz.  Instead, MASK is an inspirationally uplifting look at a boy and his mother, and how they overcome the odds and make life meaningful and important.  Cher is wonderful as the mother, a drug addicted biker chick who nonetheless is a supportive and caring parent; Eric Stoltz, unrecognizable under the Oscar winning make-up, is stoic and poignant as the physically challenged yet mentally competent young man; Sam Elliott brings his macho earthiness to the role of Gar, Cher's main squeeze who truly loves the boy; and an ingenuish Laura Dern is touching as Rocky's blind girlfriend.  With the reinstatement of Bruce Springsteen's music, the movie moves along with strong individual sequences and a three hanky ending.  A brilliant movie.

reviewText: The film "MASK"is a film that gives our generation a positive voice.A voice that says,"In the negative side of Life where there is often pain,despair,discouragement.""MASK"is a lift for the heart and spirit of humanity.This film is a true story.A story of courage,hope,determination against incredible odds.It shows how cold and judgemental society can be,especially when they lack the understanding of the afflications and suffering of their fellow humans.Rocky Dennis was an individual to admire,love,and be inspired by.Eric Stolz is a stellar actor whom I feel put his heart and soul into the portrayal of Rocky.He is one of my favorites along with Sam Elliott and Cher.Sam Elliott,perfect in the role of Gar,is a excellent father figure and has never disappointed with his acting talent.I've loved every film he has done.It's hard to nail down which film is his best,but I think this film should definitely be considered for him receiving an oscar.Cher,whom I've loved since her days with the "Sonny and Cher"show has definitely reached far beyond her talent into the acting realm ,and has not only achieved great fame as a singer and performer in concerts,but knocked fans out with her many great films.She is also a huge talent and success as a actress.This film,where she portrays Rocky Dennis mother,is very well done,she really gets into every role she takes on.Rusty Dennis had a big heart full of love and hope for her son Rocky.It was a moving experience because Cher played the role,and did it well.This film is definitely one of Cher's best.I hope that anyone who watches this film,isn't just entertained,but deeply moved and inspired as I have been.The music of Bob Seger and Bruce Springsteen makes the impact of the film even stronger.I,by the way have Cerebral Palsey.I've had it since birth.I know what it is to be treated unfairly by cruel,ignorant people,who think you're weird because you look different,don't walk "normal".Disabilities are in all of us.They don't show as much in some as they do in others.I like to think of mine as "A Little Inconvienance"Rocky Dennis triumphed over his,touching lots of hearts and lives.God Bless you Rocky,Rusty,Gar,for showing us all how to really live,beating the odds.Thanks to a compassionate mother for letting Rocky's story be told.Thanks too to a stellar cast,and a director with likewise hearts,to tell Rocky's story so warmly on the screen.To all of you fellow film buffs out there,count your blessings open your hearts,buy this film.I guarentee,you will be impressed,moved,inspired,and will never feel that you got a tougher break in life.This film speaks for all generations past and present.It is,in my opinion a blockbuster classic!
summary: "A Film That Stirs Your Soul And Touches Your Heart"

reviewText: My 10th grade english teacher told his class a story about one of his students who was in a serious car accident leaving him clinging to life and when he did survive, leaving him severely disfigured. The main thing he wanted was to go back to school, to be with friends, and live his life again. It was a sad story that our teacher told us while he choked up because he was close to this student. The student died at only age 16. As we were told the story, we thought of this movie, called the mask. The difference was, the boy in mask had a rare, unpredictable, and incurable disease. Also a true story, mask is a moving and heart-wrenching tearjerker that is good for children to watch as well as adults. It's a life lesson to appreciate what you have, and to not discriminate against others because no one is perfect. Kids can be brutally cruel and it is hard enough being a teenager and dealing with everyday problems like peer pressure, acceptance, fitting in, meeting girls etc. But to also have an extremely noticeable disfigurement and to deal with teasing and staring, and laughing, it almost seems unbearable to endure. But this boy was stronger than most, and seemed used to people's ignorance, but of course not completely unphased. I.E. When he finally falls in love with a blind girl from a summer camp, and after they all go home his calls to her are ignored. He later finds out that her parents want her to have nothing to do with him. They too, were prejudice against him which is a bit baffling considering most parents of blind children are more compassionate because they raise their children to overcome obstacles and discrimination for their disability. The fact that they were so rude to him when they first met was infuriating. The other part of the story was his mother and her drug problems and premiscuous acts. He does help her, but the stress and hardships he faces makes you constantly feel sad and angry at the people who treat him badly. It's a tearjerker but also a very important tale about courage, love, respect, and compassion.

reviewText: This is a review for the Director's Cut Widescreen EditionMask deals with the last two years of the life of Rocky Dennis.  Rocky was stricken with a disease that builds up calcium deposits on the skull, deforming the face.  While it has deformed his face, it has not changed anything else, including his spirit.The doctors are always doom and gloom but as Rusty puts it, if I started to dig a grave every time a doctor told me Rocky was going to die, I'd be eating chow mien right now!Rocky (Eric Stoltz) is about to start his last year in junior high school.  It is a new school and the principal does not want him there.  But mom, Rusty (Cher), already has that covered.  What the principal doesn't know is that Rocky is extremely bright and despite his disease, he makes friends easily.Rusty was a stereotypical biker babe of the 70's.  She was hard drinking and a drug addict.  Neither of these pleased Rocky.  In comes, old flame Gar (Sam Elliot).  Gar is definitely more centered than Rusty.  He understands what Rocky has been through and is there for him.Rusty graduates junior high school with honors and the principal arranges a scholarship at a summer camp for the blind.  At the camp he meets a beautiful blind girl, Anne (Laura Dern).  She knows that he is not normal but sees the perfect soul not the imperfect face.  The camp ends and Rusty meets the parents and of course, they are not pleased.  But when he is picked up by the crew, Rusty announces that she is clean and sober.Rocky starts High School with the usual complications.  But once again he overcomes them.  But his personal life has taken a turn for the worse.  His best friend is moving in with his father back east and is not going to Europe with Rocky.  Also, Anne's mother has prevented him from contacting her.  He finally tracks Anne down only to find out that she is being sent to a special school.With all things handed to Rocky he overcomes the disappointments.  But the doctor's predictions finally come true and Rocky succumbs to the disease.This is a film with a lot of heart and soul.  This is a film about the human spirit and the adversities that God gives us.  Cher won the Cannes Film Festival Best Actress Award.  She should have won an Oscar.  Both Stoltz and Elliott give well faceted and finely layered performances.  This is Bogdonovich's best film since The Last Picture Show.This is a director's cut and includes two scenes that the studio removed and restored the Springsteen songs that were removed before its opening.  This only makes a great film better.DVD EXTRAS:Commentary by Peter BogdonovichMask Revisited: A Conversation with Peter Bogdonovich - A 25 minute featurette where Bogdonovich talks about the making of the film from the origins to the final cut.

reviewText: I remember seeing 'Mask' on cable many years ago, but I never felt it was deep enough to be considered a great movie. This version on the special edition has restored the Springsteen sound track and some very important scenes to make this film a much more poignant experience. Cher, Stoltz, Elliott and Dern are all believable in this tragic story of the deformed youth.Stoltz who played one of Jeff Spicoli's stoner buds in 'Fast Times At Ridgemont High' and a hilarious role as Lance in 'Pulp Fiction' shows a lot of talent hidden under a ton of make-up. The DVD transfer look very good, but I noticed some softness in certain scenes. The short documentary does explain the differences in the theatrical version and this one that ended up hidden away until now. It's well worth checking out and is a much better film.

reviewText: 'Mask' is a beautiful and moving film, and manages to be such without relying on heavyhanded schmaltz, overacting or directorial overstatement. It's a wonderfully subtle tale of coming-of-age and triumphing over adversity, and one that nobody should go without seeing, at least once.Rusty Dennis (Cher) and her son Rocky (Eric Stoltz) are not your average family: she's a drug-abusing biker mom, and he's living with a medical condition that has deformed his skull and, by all medical accounts, should have killed him during childhood. Ferociously defensive and protective of her son, and when her old boyfriend Gar (Sam Elliot) returns, Rusty must deal as best she can when a series of events happen that force her to examine both her own life and that of her son: his graduation from junior high school, his first girlfriend Diana (Laura Dern) and his continued desire to look 'normal': he's growing up.The central performances from Cher and Stoltz are flawless and believable: even with the now-questionable looking makeup effects, theirs is still a convincing and thought-provoking relationship that forces the viewer to examine the traditional parent-child bond: while not the most responsible adult, Rusty's still a great mom - how can this be? And how comfortable do we feel with Rocky's constant desire to look different, or his seemingly 'easier' relationship with a girl who happens to be blind? The issue of the Urban Family is examined, too: Rusty's parents may have alienated her at a young age, and Rocky's father may be out of the picture, but how can they seem so content with the beer-swilling, joint-smoking Gar and his violent, layabout biker buddies? While the plot seems fairly simplistic to begin with, as the movie progresses, we find ourselves more and more challenged by the seeming straightforwardness of the situations: the mark of great actors and a truly great script.Direction is excellent: Bogdanovich is a real talent, and his unpretentious, pared-back, almost-amateurish style of filmmaking is the ideal compliment for this great, multi-layered story.This Director's Cut DVD is a wonderful option: the restored print is crisp and clean, and the extra scenes are a nice touch. Extras are pretty perfunctory, but Audio/Video quality is better than it's ever been.But none of those features are the reason for owning 'Mask' on DVD. Own it on any format you choose: this is a wonderfully clever, touching and masterfully-crafted piece of film. Totally recommended.

reviewText: Like so many tragedy films based on life's unexpected twists, this one truly touches your heart as a boy endears everyone with his likeable personality despite a horrible facial affliction similar to Elephantitis.  Eric Stoltz did a phenomenal job in this challenging role, and Cher performed flawlessly.  Set in the early 70s, based on a biker's lifestyle and a mother's constant struggle with drugs, the film portrays the many difficulties a single mother faced during that era despite her addictive love for a son plagued with a horrible disfigurement and her effort to give him as normal of a life as possible with a future full of hope to look forward to.  Excellent film and another classic well worth purchasing!

reviewText: This is movie is based on a true story, and centers around Rocky Dennis, a 16 year old boy who was born with severe facial deformities. Since he was a child, doctors had been telling his mother, Rusty (Cher), that Rocky would never make it through the next year of his life. However, 16 years later, he was still proving them wrong.Rocky's mother is very protective and very devoted to him, even though her personal life isn't stable. Rusty runs with a wild bunch, and parties every night, and usually spends the night with a different man. Plus, she is a drug user. This in itself is a source of tension between she and Rocky. Yet they still love one another very much and would do anything for the other. In fact, Rusty has helped Rocky immensely when he gets one of his terrible headaches, which are a result of his deformity. Rather than resorting to medicine to cure the pain, Rusty manages to literally talk Rocky through it.Gar(Sam Elliott), an old flame of Rusty's, returns to the picture, and after time, they resume their old relationship. Gar has been like a father to Rocky over the years, and is basically the only good guy that has been in Rusty and Rocky's life.The movie follows the ups and downs of their life together, as Rusty continues to battle her addictions and Rocky enters the 9th grade. He is in a new school, and has to deal with the taunts of his new set of classmates. To make things harder, he develops a crush on a girl, knowing that she will never return his feelings because of how he looks.Despite the adversity, Rocky is the smartest kid in his classes and ends up making friends by tutoring one of the popular boys. After that, he is accepted a little bit more, and ends up befriending a few others.In this version, there is a new soundtrack, using Bruce Springsteen's songs, the way it was supposed to have been released all those years ago. There is also a new scene with Rusty and Rocky, where they are hanging out with Rusty's friends at a bonfire and Rusty and Rocky sing a rendition of 'Little Egypt'. This scene is true to life, and is something the real Rusty and Rocky used to do.Another added scene is after Red, one of the oldest in the gang, dies. They have a genuine bikers funeral for him, where his motorcycle is buried alongside of him, and they fire off handguns in salute.Eric Stoltz is great as Rocky. I am not really a fan of Eric's but in this movie he delivers. Cher is great also, and is perfect in her portrayal of a troubled mother battling her addictions and inner demons. It's probably my favorite role of hers. Sam Elliott exudes sex appeal as Gar, and you can see why Rusty was so hung up on him.I could go on and on about this movie, but then I'd end up relaying the whole thing. Suffice it to say, this is a really wonderful, sad movie. If you haven't seen it, you need to.
Title: N/A

reviewText: One would have thought that after her performance in "Silkwood" Cher would have received her props in Hollywood. The Academy would later make up for overlooking her in this film by presenting her the Best Actress Oscar for "Moonstruck." But it is in "Mask,"where Cher proves her acting mettle.Cher acts and even looks the part of Rusty, the mother of a severely disfigure child; but that is almost a side note. What gives the film its ability to relate to its audience is the tension between this beleaguered woman and her on-again/off- again boyfriend Gar (Sam Elliot, delivering a subtly cool performance); and Rusty and her staunchly old-fashioned parents. Cher takes advantage of the opportunities to flaunt her acting chops without being over the top. It is here where she proves that she can more than hold her own against any of Hollywood's so-called A-list actresses.Eric Stolz plays Rocky Dennis (upon whom the story was based), and the chemistry between he and his older co-star is unmistakable. Their relationship comes off as real, without any of the parents vs. teenager cliches. Both Rocky and Rusty feel things deeply and it is that trait that binds them. Rusty is a single mother struggling with drug addiction, but never lets it get in the way of loving her child.Interesting contrast between Rocky's world and the world of the "typical teen," so much so that you don't put Rocky nor feel a need to root for him, but you enjoy him. You know that his puppy love will not end happily, but you know that Rocky will weather the storm.Moreover, her biker friends serve as an extended family to Rocky, who is played by Stolz as a kid who is all heart, and who sees himself not as one desperate to fit in, but who waits for the rest of the world to catch up to him.Wonderful performances by the actors who make up the biker gang of which Gar is a part of.  They are men of depth and compassion as they embrace Rocky as one of their own.The climax delivers one of the more emotionally charged scenes you'll ever see--comparable to "Beaches" and "Imitation Of Life." It is heart-wrenching without being sappy, showing the depth of a mother;'s love for her offspring.This is definitely one of my all-time favorite films and a must-see for those who love films that have the power to pluck an emotional chord. Good date flick because it has what it takes to touch men and women equally deeply without beating you over the head with sentimentalism. Cher and Stolz keep it real.
summary: Cher Should Have Won The Oscar

For film fans this is the version to buy.

reviewText: Rusty Dennis is the mother of Rocky, a seriously deformed but extremely intelligent and emotionally warm child. Rusty is a no-nonsense mother whose wild lifestyle is often at odds with her tenderness and protectiveness towards Rocky. She is determined that Rocky be given the same chances and happiness that everyone else takes for granted. The true story of Rocky Dennis (Eric Stoltz) is a heart-breaking movie that pulls absolutely no punches. Cher is excellent as Stoltz's drug-addicted mother who is so good with him, but so poor with most everyone else. Not to be missed by anyone with an interest in true life stories. Highly recommended. A triumph in storytelling.

reviewText: With out a question, Cher should have been nomainted and possibly won the oscar for her role in "MASK". Cher give's the perforamce of her carrer as Rusty, and with compansion and a tough as nail attiude she shows the love this woman had for her son. This release restores 2 delted scenes from the movie and couldn't be happier to have them after all these years. If you have not seen this movie, Do it now..you won't be sorry.
